posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
The partially inspired REV product release thread sparked my interest in designing a locking system for the MAXPlanetary. This V2 design features both clockwise and counter-clockwise ratchets, aiming to simplify assembly and enhance durability. Testing reveals it increases height by ~1" and width by ~0.5", offering a sleek package.

A video demo shows operation, and the system attaches between the MAXPlanetary's input stage and motor, utilizing a servo and spring linkage to control engagement. This setup prevents backdriving during autonomous climbing, a common issue in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) endgames. By reducing reliance on high gearing, the system enables faster climbers without compromising stability.

Several CAD models and BOMs confirm the design's feasibility. Future applications include integration with elevators for secure climbing. Stay tuned for more insights and feedback from the community.

posts.cooked: Could this system be designed to replace the input stage? However, that would remove the depth penalty of adding this, but it remains an excellent design nonetheless.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Design Lead & Master of Sketchy Solutions

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
So this is really interesting. If I were to make that the packaging challenge sounds fun.

You’d need to drill a shaft clearance hole into the ½" hex MAXPlanetary input adapter which would make fabricating this in season at least a bit tougher. Without doing that you’re stuck with the current dimensions as the NEO can’t go down any farther. If I did that I could honestly just make the entire thing thinner without even removing the input stage.

I’d need to have a 3D printed part support the motor and the pawl with two bolts. I’m not sure if I could design it to be strong enough.

And the last thing I’d have to design it again which would take a lot of time. I want to make sure I perfect this design first I think. Especially since the length of the MAXPlanetary doesn’t really matter for the packaging of them In most applications.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: I'd be curious if you could add a limit switch to signal the motor controller to not spin against the ratchet.

posts.name: Garrison
posts.cooked: Replacing the metal hex 3D print insert with an 8mm shaft or a spline pinion (such as one compatible with Kraken) may help address the shaft clearance issue.

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked: The servo already includes a potentiometer for position control. A software lockout can be achieved by monitoring the servo's position. A limit switch may not be necessary. Regarding the main topic, this is a really cool design! I'm definitely curious about its performance on a robot.

posts.name: Travis Norris
posts.cooked:
This is awesome! The ratchets are designed to engage snugly with the hex insert teeth rather than being simply aligned, which eliminates potential weak points. A thoughtful approach to ratchet design ensures durability and reliability.  

A simple yet effective method to distinguish different ratchet versions externally might involve incorporating unique text labels or symbols within the linkage arms themselves.

posts.name: Unnatural Twilight
posts.cooked: That all makes sense. I wasn’t really considering in-season fabrication time, and your point about it being a tight fit is valid. I’m not sure I’d want a 3D print supporting a climb motor either.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Design Lead & Master of Sketchy Solutions

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
If the system’s reliability isn’t sufficient for controlling the servo accurately, running it at all may not be advisable. Given the critical nature of a climb operation, which could severely damage the robot if the servo fails, extreme reliability is essential. A limit switch appears to have already been omitted in the system design, indicating a flaw in its functionality.

For those seeking enhanced system feedback, Taiga’s analog feedback micro servo offers a straightforward solution. However, incorporating a limit switch would introduce more points of failure, added complexity, and increase the bill of materials by approximately $25 per unit.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I think that approach could really help. I need to investigate the thinnest gears available for an insert, and while MAXSwerve pinions might be a viable option, I should also examine how a key interacts with this system. Additionally, I realize I may have become overly focused on using a ttb hex insert early on in the design process.  

I plan to create a prototype based on this idea soon.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Interesting design. I'm curious about its durability under load. Given the servo pushing against a spring, which seems to be the only resistance, I wonder if a different mechanism might offer better reliability. While a spring provides some ratcheting effect, I believe there could be more robust solutions available.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: This will not release under load. You would need to write a bit of code to tell it "retract the pawl" and then move forward just a touch to unload.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: A machined part allows you to shrink, press, loctite, or screw it onto the outside diameter (OD) of a standard Max planetary input adapter. Printed parts, however, present significant challenges due to insufficient torque transmitting capacity. While you might attempt to align them slightly off-center with cross pins, doing so risks damaging the part, particularly with splined adapters where crossing into the shaft hole can cause severe issues.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I’m a bit curious to know if it would release under load or not.

This does release under load, at least when tested with me manually giving the load (turning the input adapter by hand). It’s because of the pawl’s design, it doesn’t really lock. The pawl’s interface with the ratchet is an arc with a centerpoint of the pivot rather than a straight line, so the pawl doesn’t have to push the ratchet at all. This may be worse for durability, but I think it should be fine. If it ends up being a failure point when testing, I’ll change it.

given the servo would be pushing against what appears to be nothing but a spring.

While it is just a spring, the force required for this is counterintuitive. It appears that the spring is more than strong enough for the job, at least when testing it using my hands. I’ll have to wait until the shop is open for me to thoroughly test it. If it’s a problem I’ll look into other solutions.

With a machined part you could shrink/press/loctite/setscrew it onto the OD of a standard MAXPlanetary input adapter.

While I’m sure this would work, I’d prefer to keep the BOM down and make it as simple as possible for everyone to implement this onto their robot. Many teams do not have access to machining tools, and a lot do have access to a 3D printer. Additionally, for this to be on your robot you need to fabricate it in season so this should be as easy as possible.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Working on a Kraken-flavored version with a spline in the pawl...

Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

This is a blog post about the WildStang Robotics Program, discussing progress made toward building a robot for the upcoming regional competition. The team is nearing completion of the mechanical components. Additionally, the post includes information about a locking mechanism known as the MAXPlanetary Locking system, which is crucial for securing parts. The timing is tight, with only two and a half weeks left before the regional event. The team is focusing on finalizing the robot design and preparing for the competition.

accepted_answer.excerpt: We really struggled with the tiny tension spring on this design. So we modified it to use an elastic band to load the pawl instead. We mounted it this evening and can confirm it works well! @Eliot [PXL_20250310_211930949.MP] [image-3]
